The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.

```I live in Baltimore.  I work as a solar salesman.  I love music and cologne and jeans and sneakers.  I can talk about music and my dog cookie.  My goals are to be more organized and get my shit together.  I also want to learn more about AI music like Suno and Udio.  here is my facebook https://www.facebook.com/mark.manthy```

The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```you can be as casual as you want.  you can call me mark.  answers should be as long as they need to be.  I want you to have opinions because that makes you more interesting.```

parts: What are some Christmas things to do in NYC tomorrow

content.text: search("What are some Christmas things to do in NYC tomorrow ")

parts:
Hey Mark,

If you're planning to spend tomorrow, Sunday, December 22, 2024, in New York City, there are plenty of festive activities to immerse yourself in the holiday spirit. Here are some top recommendations:

**1. Ice Skating at Iconic Rinks**

- **The Rink at Rockefeller Center**: Skate under the famous Christmas tree in a quintessential NYC holiday experience.

- **Wollman Rink in Central Park**: Enjoy skating with a backdrop of the Manhattan skyline.

**2. Visit Holiday Markets**

- **Bryant Park Winter Village**: Explore over 180 vendors offering unique gifts and enjoy the free admission ice skating rink (skate rentals available). citeturn0news20

- **Union Square Holiday Market**: Discover artisan crafts and festive foods in this bustling market.

**3. Attend a Holiday Show**

- **Radio City Christmas Spectacular**: Experience the high-kicking Rockettes in this classic holiday performance. citeturn0news16

- **The Magic Flute at The Metropolitan Opera**: Enjoy Mozart's enchanting opera, suitable for all ages. citeturn0news13

**4. Admire Festive Window Displays**

- **Fifth Avenue Stores**: Stroll along Fifth Avenue to see the elaborate holiday window displays at stores like Bergdorf Goodman and Macy's. citeturn0news21

**5. Explore Dyker Heights Christmas Lights**

- **Dyker Heights, Brooklyn**: Wander through this neighborhood renowned for its extravagant holiday light displays. citeturn0search4

**6. Visit the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree**

- **Rockefeller Plaza**: Marvel at the iconic Christmas tree, adorned with thousands of lights and a Swarovski star. citeturn0search0

**7. Attend a Holiday Concert**

- **The New York Pops at Carnegie Hall**: Enjoy a festive concert featuring holiday classics. citeturn0news13

**8. Explore the New York Botanical Garden's Holiday Train Show**

- **Bronx**: View model trains zipping through a display of more than 175 New York landmarks, each re-created with natural materials. citeturn0search6

**9. Enjoy a Holiday Cruise**

- **Classic Harbor Line Holiday Cruises**: Take a cozy cruise with views of the city skyline and Statue of Liberty, complete with holiday music and cocoa. citeturn0search4

**10. Visit the Holiday Under the Palms at Brookfield Place**

- **Brookfield Place, Tribeca**: Experience a tropical-themed holiday display with palm trees adorned with lights, along with shopping and dining options. citeturn0search5

Before heading out, consider the weather forecast:

forecastturn0forecast0

Dress warmly and plan your activities accordingly. Enjoy your festive day in NYC!

content_references.title: 6 NYC Christmas Markets Worth a Holiday Visit
content_references.snippet: New York City is renowned for its festive Christmas markets that flourish from late November to the end of December, complementing other holiday attractions like The Nutcracker, Radio City Rockettes' Christmas Spectacular, and Rockefeller Center Christmas tree. Among the best markets is the Bank of America Winter Village at Bryant Park, featuring over 180 vendors, an ice rink, and cozy heated igloos. Coney Island’s Frost Fest at Luna Park offers photos with Santa, a tree lighting, rides, and a holiday market. Grand Central Holiday Fair is perfect for indoor shopping, featuring 36 local vendors and a holiday train show. Macy's Holiday Square and The Herald Holiday Market in Herald Square present curated seasonal gifts and food vendors post-Thanksgiving parade. Downtown Brooklyn’s The Makers Show at City Point offers local crafts on select December weekends. Lastly, the bustling Union Square Holiday Market boasts 185 vendors and is ideal for diverse holiday gifting, albeit best visited on weekday mornings to avoid crowds.

content_references.title: How the Radio City Rockettes Prepare to Dance 90-Minute Shows All Holiday Season Long
content_references.snippet:
The Rockettes’ Christmas Spectacular in New York City is a beloved holiday tradition, noted for its elaborate costumes and high-energy performances. Preparing for their rigorous 90-minute shows involves hours of rehearsal and considerable physical training. Dancers practice six days a week for six hours a day over six weeks and maintain their fitness year-round. The process includes intense training not only in dance but also cardiovascular fitness to handle up to 200 kicks per show. The Rockettes also rely on support from athletic trainers and physical therapists to stay injury-free.

New Rockette members face a competitive audition process, often trying multiple times before making the cut. Seasoned Rockettes, even after multiple years, must re-audition annually to earn their place. Veterans provide valuable advice to newcomers, helping them acclimate and perform to the best of their abilities.

The Rockettes' commitment extends beyond performances, as they bond deeply with each other, creating lifelong friendships and support systems. They feel honored to be part of a historical and iconic institution, with many having been inspired by the Rockettes from a young age. This deep sense of tradition and community drives their passion for the craft and connects them to each other and the audiences they perform for.

content_references.title: These family-centric holiday shows are taking center stage
content_references.snippet: This holiday season, various family-friendly shows in New York City offer festive entertainment for all ages. "A Christmas Carol: A Neurodiverse Retelling" by EPIC Players Theatre reinterprets the classic tale with comedic elements (Dec. 10-15). Whoopi Goldberg stars in the returning musical "Annie" at Madison Square Garden (until Jan. 5). The "Jazzukah Project" presents jazz-infused Chanukah music at the Museum at Eldridge Street (Dec. 25), while Julie Taymor's production of "The Magic Flute" brings Mozart's opera to the Metropolitan Opera (Dec. 12-Jan. 4). The New York Pops' annual holiday concert at Carnegie Hall features Jessica Vosk (Dec. 20-21). "Yuletide Factory!" by Cirque Mechanics at New Victory Theater showcases acrobatics and circus acts (until Dec. 29). Various adaptations of "The Nutcracker" include performances by the Ukrainian Grand Kyiv Ballet, "The Hip Hop Nutcracker" with Kurtis Blow, and "Nut/Cracked" by The Bang Group, blending multiple dance styles (Dec. 14, 19, and 23).

content_references.title: NYC's dazzling holiday window displays from Bergdorf, Macy's and Bloomingdale's as Saks pulls back
content_references.snippet: New York City's department stores are celebrating the holiday season with dazzling window displays that embody the festive spirit and capture the imagination of locals and visitors. Bloomingdale's features a "Wicked Good Holiday" theme inspired by "Wicked," showcasing the personalities of Glinda and Elphaba with animatronics and vintage props. Bergdorf Goodman celebrates the 200th anniversary of Fifth Avenue with "Toast of the Town," highlighting iconic New York landmarks and intricate details. Macy's presents its 150th year of holiday displays with a "Give Love" theme featuring whimsical vignettes and contributions from Big Brothers Big Sisters mentees. Saks Fifth Avenue focuses on fashion with windows featuring designs by renowned designers, complemented by a luxurious facade. Nordstrom's flagship store transforms into "The Blizz on 57th Street," a visual spectacle with large inflatable characters. Each store offers a unique holiday experience, creating a joyful atmosphere throughout the city. The displays will be on view until early January.
